title: Artemis II Crew Ready to Fly Around the Moon on “Integrity”
summary: Today the four Artemis II crew members announced the name they have chosen for their Orion capsule — Integrity. During an hour-long news conference, they conveyed readiness for their mission […]
detailed_news: Artemis II crew members announced the name they have chosen for their Orion capsule — Integrity. The goal is to fly around the Moon, but the spacecraft and life support systems first must pass tests in Earth orbit before NASA decides to execute the Trans-Lunar Injection (TLI) burn. The crew said today enabling Artemis III is their measure of success. Space weather is caused by coronal mass ejections (CMEs) from the Sun. CMEs create breathtaking auroras on Earth, but also can disrupt electrical systems and orbiting satellites. Artemis II crew can shelter in Orion’s storage compartments if there is a CME during their 10-day flight.

summary: The martian landscape is not the easiest terrain to get around. For a flying drone, such a navigation issue can mean the difference between a safe landing and a crash. Dielof van Loon, a student from Delft University of Technology, investigated what would happen if the two explorers – rover and drone – teamed up.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4661-4667: Peaking Into the Hollows
summary: By Susanne P. Schwenzer, Professor of Planetary Mineralogy at The Open University, UK Earth planning date: Friday, Sept. 19, 2025 Curiosity is currently driving along the ridges of a very uneven terrain. One of the bigger ridges we nicknamed “Autobahn,” which is the German word for a highway. But the rover didn’t stay on that […]
detailed_news: Curiosity is currently driving along the ridges of a very uneven terrain. One of the bigger ridges we nicknamed “Autobahn,” which is the German word for a highway. DAN informs us about hydrogen in the subsurface underneath the rover. Mastcam and ChemCam are taking images of many different features in the landscape. Rocks outside the crater rim, 90 kilometers away (about 56 miles) were taken with the remote micro-imager of ChemCam and with added Mastcam context. They show what will have been the source region for some of the sediments we saw very early in the mission. You can spot some patterns, too. The ridge tops are more smooth, mostly at least.

title: Chinese spacecraft image Maxar remote sensing and U.S. early warning satellites
summary:
Chinese spacecraft have imaged orbiting U.S. commercial and military assets as the two countries seek to demonstrate and assess respective capabilities.
The post Chinese spacecraft image Maxar remote sensing and U.S. early warning satellites appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Chinese spacecraft have imaged orbiting U.S. commercial and military assets. The images were taken by CGST’s Jilin-1 remote sensing constellation satellites. CGST originally planned a 138-satellite constellation, but announced in 2022 that it aims to more than double this to 300 satellites. Shiyan-12 (02) made a close approach Sept. 11 to an early warning satellite. Shiyan satellites are experimental spacecraft which analysts believe are used to trial new systems. The series appear to have been used for a range of purposes, including technology demonstrations. While many Shiyan satellites operate in low Earth or near-polar orbits, a number have recently headed to GEO, while the Shiyan-10 designation satellites entered Molniya orbits.

title: NASA, SpaceX set to launch IMAP and rideshare payloads to study space weather at L1
summary:
NASA and SpaceX are set for the launch of the agency’s Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration…
The post NASA, SpaceX set to launch IMAP and rideshare payloads to study space weather at L1 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: NASA and SpaceX are set for the launch of the agency’s Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe (IMAP) from Florida on Wednesday morning. Joining IMAP atop a Falcon 9 are two additional rideshare payloads. IMAP will fly to the Sun-Earth Lagrange Point 1 (L1), which is located between the Sun and our planet, approximately 1.5 million km away from Earth. IMAP is expected to answer four critical questions that have plagued heliophysics for decades. IMAP is relatively small, massing 900 kg and measuring just 2.4 m in diameter and 0.9 m in height. Despite this small size, IMAP’s engineers and scientists implemented 10 scientific instruments on the spacecraft. NOAA’s SWFO-L1 spacecraft is joining IMAP on its journey to L1. The observatory is the first satellite to be dedicated to continuous, operational space weather observations. The Carruthers Geocorona Observatory will investigate the geoc orona, Earth's outermost atmosphere.  NASASpaceflight.com will be taking part in the 25th anniversary of the space shuttle program. The program will take place between September 22, 2025 and April 11, 2025. The first shuttle mission will take off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on September 22. The mission will be followed by a series of other flights over the next few years.

title: U.S. military sees China’s reusable rocket push as a space security concern
summary:
Space Force leaders said Beijing’s pursuit of reusable orbital rockets underscores the national security value of the technology — and raises alarm about how China might use it once it reaches maturity
The post U.S. military sees China’s reusable rocket push as a space security concern appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: U.S. military officials are warning that China’s rapid progress in the field could one day erode that lead. Reusable rockets have dramatically lowered launch costs and increased launch frequency. China sees reusability as a linchpin for its own ambitions. For now, the United States retains the upper hand. The Space Force is also tracking China’s TJS satellites. U.S. observers believe they are being used for electronic intelligence, missile warning. “This year alone, the Chinese have put about five of them on orbit,” Lerch said.

title: A geologist, a former SpaceX launch director and a commercial astronaut; meet NASA’s 10 new astronaut candidates
summary: The cohort of ten women and men will train for the next two years to become eligible for mission assignments to low Earth orbit and beyond. This is the first astronaut candidate class to consist of more women than men.
detailed_news: The collection of ten women and men from across the United States were selected from more than 8,000 applications submitted. They represent the 24th astronaut candidate (ASCAN) class picked by NASA. Among the six women in this group is Anna Menon, the first astronaut candidate in history who has flown in orbital space prior to being selected as a NASA astronaut. NASA has added extra safeguards to the agency’s standard pre-launch quarantine protocol to protect astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley from the coronavirus and other contagions. title: Launch Roundup: Kuiper, Starlink, IMAP headline launch manifest
summary:
A busy slate of launches is planned for the last full week of September, including…
The post Launch Roundup: Kuiper, Starlink, IMAP headline launch manifest appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: A busy slate of launches is planned for the last full week of September, including flights for two major low-Earth orbit broadband constellations. China and Rocket Lab are also planning flights, with Electron set to fly two suborbital hypersonic research missions from Wallops Island, Virginia. The United Launch Alliance (ULA) is planning to fly an Atlas V 551 on the KA-03 mission for the Amazon Kuiper constellation, while SpaceX is preparing to fly four Falcon 9 Starlink missions. The Jielong 3 rocket is capable of flying up to 1,600 kg to a 500 km altitude. The rocket will carry the Jili (Geely) Constellation 06 satellites A through K. The Geely communications satellite constellation is designed to offer coverage for the Internet of Things. The IMAP spacecraft will study the boundary between the heliosphere and interstellar space. The United Launch Alliance has scheduled its third Atlas V flight of the year for Thursday, Sept. 25. Amazon is racing to launch as many Kuiper satellites as possible before a July 2026 deadline. China is planning to fly a Chang Zheng 2D (CZ-2D) on Friday, September 26, at 17:20 UTC. The third Starlink launch of this week is scheduled for Sunday, Sept. 28 at 3:30 AM EDT (07:30 UTC) from SLC-40 at the CCSFS. The rocket will take a northeast trajectory and will fly a batch of Starlink v2 Mini satellites to low-Earth orbit inclined 53.16 degrees to the Equator. This is the ninth CZ-6 series launch of 2025.

title: NASA Chooses 10 New Astronaut Candidates
summary: NASA introduced its 24th class of astronauts today, six women and four men. It is the first astronaut class with more women than men and the first with anyone who […]
detailed_news: NASA introduced its 24th class of astronauts today, six women and four men. It is the first astronaut class with more women than men and the first with anyone who already has made an orbital spaceflight. The 10 astronaut candidates will train for two years before becoming eligible for NASA missions to Earth orbit, the Moon and beyond. The other ASCANs are equally impressive as detailed in NASA’s press release. Ben Bailey is a U.S. Naval Test Pilot School graduate with more than 2,000 flight hours in more than 30 different rotary and fixed-wing aircraft. His first spaceflight is scheduled for next year on Soyuz MS-29. Anna Menon, 39, is from Houston and earned her bachelor’s degree from Texas Christian University. Imelda Muller, 34, considers Copake Falls, New York, her hometown. Erin Overcash is a former Marine Corps AH-1 attack helicopter pilot and experimental test pilot.

title: Air Force Secretary warns of ‘Sputnik moment’ as U.S. faces China’s rapid military advances

detailed_news: Air Force Secretary Troy Meink likens today's threats to the Sputnik shock of 1957. He warns that the United States risks falling behind adversaries, particularly China. title: NASA selects new astronaut class
summary:
NASA announced its newest class of astronauts Sept. 22 as agency leaders and lawmakers emphasized their intent to return humans to the moon before China.
The post NASA selects new astronaut class appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: NASA announced its newest class of astronauts Sept. 22. The six women and four men represent NASA’s first astronaut class with more women than men. The class includes scientists, engineers and pilots, with experience ranging from flying military aircraft in combat to working on the Curiosity Mars rover. NASA’s Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel raised similar concerns at a Sept. 19 meeting. “I’ll be damned if the Chinese beat NASA, or beat America, back to the moon. We’re going to win,” Sean Duffy said. Duffy did not directly address recent criticism of Artemis.
